content:
While Peter and Paul shared the same commitment to Jesus and the message of the Gospel, they had some disagreements in their teachings and practices. One of the most significant disagreements they had was related to Gentile converts to Christianity and whether or not they needed to follow Jewish dietary laws and be circumcised.

According to Galatians 2:11-14, Peter was eating with Gentile Christians in Antioch until some Jewish Christians arrived from James. At that point, Peter withdrew from eating with the Gentiles, fearing the backlash from the Jewish Christians. Paul confronted Peter over this, accusing him of hypocrisy, and insisting that their dietary customs are not a basis for Christian fellowship.

Paul believed that salvation was available to all through faith in Christ, including Gentiles, and that adherence to Jewish customs was unnecessary for salvation. Peter initially struggled with this idea but ultimately accepted it and even defended Paul's teaching at the Council of Jerusalem.

Despite their differences, Peter and Paul generally got along well, and they actually had an important partnership in spreading the Gospel. Paul even refers to Peter as a "pillar" of the Church in Galatians 2:9. Both shared a deep respect for one another, and Peter's teachings and leadership in the early Church helped establish the foundation for Paul's ministry to Gentiles.

Overall, while there were some disagreements between Peter and Paul, they worked together towards a common goal of spreading the Gospel and establishing the Christian Church.
